poem:
### Exe Men

In the green expanse  
where cider orchards breathe,  
rugby boots churn earth—  
echoing the calves of Rippon or Sidmouth,  
a family's signal strength.  
Once, minnows swam here,  
but now—  
in the roar and rush—  
listen:  
the undercurrents of victory  
blaze through Exeter's humble pastures.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Exe Men review – entertaining rugby drama tackles triumph of underdogs Exeter Chiefs Driving to this theatre, I passed signs to Sidmouth and Tiverton, more known for West Country charm than sporting supremacy. They are namechecked early in a play about the region’s recent rugby union history to make the point that, in the early 80s, Exeter used to lose to neighbourhood clubs considered minnows. Exe Men is adapted by Ashley Pharoah from Guardian rugby". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Exe Men review – entertaining rugby drama tackles triumph of underdogs Exeter Chiefs Driving to this theatre, I passed signs to Sidmouth and Tiverton, more known for West Country charm than sporting supremacy. They are namechecked early in a play about the region’s recent rugby union history to make the point that, in the early 80s, Exeter used to lose to neighbourhood clubs considered minnows. Exe Men is adapted by Ashley Pharoah from Guardian rugby
